page.title: 05Railways 1862-1985 Part 2
page.content: During the 1939-1945 war, the line was very important in a number of ways. Because of enemy action, the lines around the north of London, in particular the North London Railway were frequently blocked. The Cambridge, Sandy, Bedford, Bletchley line was used for diverted freight trains from East Anglia and Lincolnshire to Southampton, South Wales and the West Country. Large numbers of personnel were moved along the line to the many R.A.F and U.S.A.A.F airfields in East Anglia, together with supplies, including munitions. After the war, traffic reverted to a few freight trains for mainly local produce and the passenger trains.
